questiontext.text:

\\[g(x) = \\frac{x}{x-{@a@}}\\]

\\(h(x) = e^{{@b@}x}\\)

\\(f \\circ g \\circ h =\\) [[input:ans1]] 

[[validation:ans1]]
Which one of the following statements is false?

feedback.text: The statement is true. It follows from properties of logarithms, noting that for all \\( x \\in \\mathbb{R} \\) the arguments of the logarithms in the expression are always positive.

answer.text: \\( \\log_{10}( x y^2) = \\frac{\\ln(x) + 2 \\ln(y)}{\\ln(10)} \\) for all positive numbers \\( x\\) and \\(y\\).

feedback.text: The statement is true. Don\'t forget the base change formula for logarithms!

You are correct, this is false! That\'s because the right-hand-side \\( 4 \\ln(1+x) \\ln(x) \\) is only defined for \\( x > 0 \\). The statement is then only true for positive \\(x \\), not for all \\( x \\in \\mathbb{R} \\).
The statement is true, by definition of inverse functions, as long as \\( x > -1 \\) (so that the argument of the logarithm is positive).

feedback.text:
Well done! Indeed, for all \\( x \\in [0,\\pi] \\), we have \\( \\sin^2 x \\leq 1 \\), and \\( \\sin^2 x \\) is always positive. Thus
